plainDefinition: Borrowed money that lets you control a larger position with less cash.
example: With 5× leverage, $100 controls $500; a 2% drop ≈ $10 loss.
whyItMatters: Amplifies both gains and losses. Use with a stop-loss.

plainDefinition: The cash you must set aside to open/keep a leveraged position.
whyItMatters: Falling below required margin can trigger liquidation.

plainDefinition: An instruction to close a trade at a set price to limit loss.
Close a trade at a set price to lock in gains.
whyItMatters: Automates exits to avoid giving back gains.

plainDefinition: Difference between buy (ask) and sell (bid) price.
whyItMatters: You pay the spread when entering/exiting.

plainDefinition: Execution at a different price than requested.
example: Market order at $10 fills $10.02 in fast markets.

plainDefinition: Buy/sell at a specific price or better.
example: Buy limit $10 fills at $10 or lower.

plainDefinition: Buy/sell immediately at current market price.
Profit and Loss — the money gained or lost.
Forced position close when margin is insufficient.
example: Large adverse move at 10× can liquidate quickly.
